results.title: Images of the land: 100 years of Australian landscapes
results.creator_credit: Ian Stocks and Queensland Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Highlights the work of some of Australia’s most important artists from the 19th century to the present time. Includes the works of Arthur Streeton, Hans Heysen, Russell Drysdale, Sidney Nolan, Fred Williams and others who present us with their visions of the Australian landscape.

results.title: Hard work and hope: Australia's Italians
results.creator_credit: Equality Press and Italian Historical Society
results.brief_description: Designed to enable Australian Studies students appreciate the role of migrant labour in Australia. Focuses on the theme of work as experienced by Italian immigrants both before and after World War II. Photographs, newsreel footage and moving footage from the Italian Historical Society documents the contribution of Australia’s Italians to the community through their work. Accompanied by a 19p. Teacher’s Guide.

results.title: Make It Right
results.creator_credit: Central and Northern Land Councils and Inst of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies
results.brief_description: An impressionistic account of the Prime Minister, Bob Hawke’s, 1988 visit to the Barunga Festival in remote Northern Territory. Thousands of Aboriginal people travel to this, the largest Aboriginal sports and cultural festival in Australia. In this particular year Mr. Hawke received a petition from the Aboriginal people for recognition of their rights, and in turn he pledged the drawing up of a treaty between black and white Australia. This treaty has yet to be made.

results.title: Aboriginal Education in Victoria: VAECG
results.creator_credit: Vincent O'Donnell, Melbourne State College. Media Production Centre and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description: Explains the workings of the Victorian Aboriginal Education Consultative Group. Shows how the group operates with Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people in Shepparton, Robinvale and Echuca. Introduced by Norman Lacy, Assistant Minister of Education.

results.title: Broken white line
results.brief_description: A documentation of the role of an Aboriginal social worker, depicting the enormity of the problems he is called upon to help solve in the Aboriginal community. DUE TO THE NATURE OF THE MATERIAL, TEACHER PREVIEW OF THE FILM BEFORE CLASSROOM SCREENING IS ESSENTIAL.

results.title: Even chance
results.creator_credit: Martin Zierman, Sabina Baltrukomis, Curriculum Branch, Ministry of Ed and Victoria. Office of the Commissioner for Equal Opportunity
results.brief_description: Alice, a young Aboriginal woman, leaves her home in a country town to work in the city. She finds employment but things start to go wrong and eventually she is dismissed. Alice decides to take her case to the Office of the Commissioner for Equal Opportunity. The program highlights examples of harassment, prejudice, stereotyping and discrimination.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Martin Zierman, Sabina Baltrukomis, Curriculum Branch, Ministry of Ed and Victoria. Office of the Commissioner for Equal Opportunity

results.title: Settle down country
results.creator_credit: David Batty, Jim Buckell, Pam Nathan, CAAC, CAAMA, NAIHO and Western Deserts Oustations Council
results.brief_description: Documents the return of the Pintubi people to their own lands after many years on Government run settlements. Extensive use of archival footage offers an added historical perspective to this account of the efforts of these people to retain their cultural heritage. Based on the book of the same name by Dick Leichleitner Japanangka and Pam Nathan.

results.title: Aboriginal bark painting
results.creator_credit: Latrobe University. School of Education. Media Centre
results.brief_description: Made in partnership with the Barinaga Aboriginal Co-operative at Maningrida, Northern Territory. Provides an informative look at the bark paintings of Arnhem Land, placing the art work firmly in the context of Aboriginal belief systems and using traditional techniques. A useful complement to “The art and craft of Maningrida”. Narrated by Robin Cuming.

results.title: Whitewashed
results.creator_credit: Sue Ross and New South Wales Institute of Technology
results.brief_description: Examines the removal of Aboriginal children from their families and their placement in foster homes with white parents, the effect upon the children and the continuation of the practice in NSW today.

results.title: Chocolates, giants and peaches. Parts 1, 2 and 3
results.creator_credit: Lily Steiner, Statewide School Support and Victoria. Ministry of Education
results.brief_description: Roald Dahl, recorded live at the Dallas Brooks Hall in Melbourne, talks about his writing and reads aloud from his own books, including Revolting Rhymes”, “BFG”, “Charlie and the Chocolate Factory”, “Matilda and “Dirty Beasts”.
